pullRequest.body:
Reported [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Splitting.20Mathlib.2FData.2FFinset.2FBasic/near/473746566).

The PR corrects the checks to only allow "small" increases to the value of the option.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [d57127874a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17309/commits/d57127874aba4d0ac7a34dd4f309fc1bc13587cb)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Thank you for working on this - and I am really happy there are thorough tests for this now. This logic is complex enough that holding it all in my head is error-prone, as we saw :-)

I just saw another pre-existing issue: there are two more references to 1500 in the file. Feel free to file a PR with just that change, label it `easy` and `maintainer merge` on my behalf. (I'll be without github access until the end of the week.)
awaiting-author
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
CI‚ÄØis unhappy atm
Fixed the CI failure.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11358070645/job/31591991805)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11358070645/job/31591991566)

I just re-read everything again and pushed a commit with a few last tweaks. (In particular, I removed the "you can disable this linter" message from the newly added branch: the user decided to configure this lint, so there seems to be no need to tell them about removing it, right? That lint only applies to mathlib anyway, which would not want to disallow the linter. Feel free to revert that one, if you disagree.)
maintainer merge

I took a look again. I remember how sufficiently subtle this is - hence, my review is focusing on test coverage. If there are tests for every edge case and we agree the linter behaves sensible there, I'll be more confident the logic is actually correct :-)

I also have a few minor tweaks, as usual. Thanks for continuing to work on this. I appreciate that landing this one is a bit of a nightmare, because
- you have to page all the fiddly details into your head, and
- the reviewer also needs to do so,
- ideally quickly enough for you to not lose that context.
Perhaps adding more tests can break this loop...
Michael, thank you for the review!  I added some tests.

I just re-read everything again and pushed a commit with a few last tweaks. (In particular, I removed the "you can disable this linter" message from the newly added branch: the user decided to configure this lint, so there seems to be no need to tell them about removing it, right? That lint only applies to mathlib anyway, which would not want to disallow the linter. Feel free to revert that one, if you disagree.)
maintainer merge

```suggestion
set_option linter.style.longFile 1800
```

Good idea to add a comment!
```suggestion
    -- In this case, the file has an allowed length, and the linter option is unnecessarily set.

```
    -- Note that either `lastLine ‚â§ defValue` and `defValue = linterBound` hold or
    -- `candidate` is necessarily bigger than `lastLine` and hence bigger than `defValue`.
Note to self: triple-check this logic; I am not fully convinced any more that these are *all* possible cases.

```suggestion
    -- In this case, the file is longer than the default and also than what the option says.

What do you think about setting this to the default value instead? I wouldn't want to change that default and break the test... (similarly, auditing this file for occurrences of the number 1500 seems useful)
Can you add another test setting the option to something *smaller* than the default (i.e., 100 lines or so) --- the goal being to test the very first error message. That seems to be missing.

> Can you add another test setting the option to something _smaller_ than the default (i.e., 100 lines or so) --- the goal being to test the very first error message. That seems to be missing.

The very first test of the file verifies that 1500 is not allowed.  I added a test for 1999 at the end of the file, after setting the default value to 2000, to make sure that the check uses `defValue`, rather than `1500`.  I did not add it next to the one that is already checking this, since it would involve re-checking manually that the claimed error that is not tested is still up to date.
By the way, there are three `1500`s in the linter file: two are in doc-strings and one is the default value of the linter.  The rest of the file uses the variables, rather than the number.
I found one case clearer with replacing it - but agree on the other ones!
Can you check that some test fails if you remove the second condition in the `if`? If not, please add a test :-)

I had placed that extra condition to help readability, but it should never happen in real code:
* if `linterBound` has been altered, a previous check already makes sure that it is strictly bigger than the `defValue`;
* if `linterBound` has not been altered, then it should be equal to `defValue`.

However, by messing around with the `defValue` twice, once to allow a small `linterBound` and then again to make the previous change illegal later on, I added a test for this.
Thanks!
It seems we have a test for this, when the default value is exceeded. Can you also add one where it's equal? (I don't want to have to worry about off-by-one errors, but have a test having my back.)

The previous test that is checking an "almost impossible situation" is flimsy enough, since it is hard to make sure that the "message that would have been printed had the condition not been included" is not verified.

Hence, I think that adding yet another such test would not be especially useful.
Fair enough: I'm also won't object to not verifying that situation super closely.

You *could* phrase this check differently:
- check early if the default value is not a multiple of 100 (which seems desirable regardless, right)
- then, just compare candidate and linterBound + 200 here
Given the first change, you could then make the error message clearer: the limit is *too high* and should be lowered.
In practice, the limit *will be* too high, but the user would also see that since the linter explicitly mentions all values/bounds.  I am tempted to not touch this.  Would you agree?
As I said above: a test which makes the allowed option far too large would also be nice. Thanks!
I added a test at the end, setting the `defValue` to 400 and the `linterBound` to 5000.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - fix: make the long file linter reject "too large" values
